React

React (sometimes also called React.js or ReactJS), is an open-source JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It was developed by Facebook. It is used in the creation of interactive and reusable UI (User Interface) components. React can be used on both the client side and server side. This JavaScript library allows you to turn a complex UI into simple and reusable components.

React allows developers to create large applications that use data which can change over time without the need to reload the page. React also provides a template language and functions to render HTML.

Because React uses a Virtual DOM, it only updates the real DOM when required, allowing the application to have great performance. A re-render can only therefore be triggered if a component's state has changed.

React is only the view layer. ReactDOM is a standalone library that is used to render React components on the DOM. React will only output HTML. React is simply: The 'V' in 'MVC'.

React only corresponds to the View layer in the Model-View-Controller (MVC) template. React can also be used alongside other JavaScript libraries or frameworks.

JSX is a preprocessor step that adds XML syntax to JavaScript. React can be used without JSX, but JSX makes React a lot more elegant. Just like XML, JSX tags have a tag name, attributes and children. If an attribute value is enclosed in quotes, the value is a string. If the value is within braces, the value is a JavaScript expression.

It is recommended to use JSX when using React as it describes what the UI (User Interface) should look like and produces React elements.

Since JSX is closer to JavaScript than HTML, React DOM uses camelCase property naming convention instead of HTML attribute names. For example, class becomes className in JSX, and tabindex becomes tabIndex.

Because JSX is not supported in current browsers by default, we have to compile it into JavaScript.

Since JSX is JavaScript, identifiers such as class and for are discouraged, and instead, React DOM components expect DOM property names such as: className to be used.

Install React

Using the NPM (Node Package Manager) Create React App package, is the easiest way to start building a React single page application (SPA). Begin by opening a terminal and enter the following commands. The my-app part of the command is the name of your application.

			

// If you need to install the create-react-app package
$ npm install -g create-react-app

// Create a new React application if create-react-app is already installed
$ create-react-app my-app

$ cd my-app
$ npm start

This process does not handle backend logic or databases, just the frontend of the build pipeline. Any backend can then be used. Once the process has been completed using the command above, a directory containing the application named my-app is created.

create-react-app uses the Babel and Webpack build tools, so you can use ES6 JavaScript syntax.

ES6 support in React was introduced in version 0.13.0. ES6 code is transpiled into ES5 for use in browsers using the Babel transpiler.

When you use the command npm start, a local server is started and the application will be visible using the URL: http://localhost:3000, although the browser will be opened by default.

When your ready to deploy your React application to production, run the following command. This will build your application for production inside the build folder within your project directory.

			

$ npm run build

The React documentation recommends using React with Babel to let you use ES6 and/or JSX in your code. ES6 is the modern JavaScript syntax and includes new features to make development easier. JSX is an extension to the JavaScript language that works well with React.

It is recommended to install babel-preset-react and babel-preset-es2015 and to create a .babelrc config file to use Babel.

Babel is a compiler and lets you write modern JavaScript code that still works in older browsers.

A modern build pipeline typically consists of: Package manager, bundler and compiler.

Simple Application

We are going to create a very simple application. When the create-react-app package is used to create a new application, the file structure will look like this:

			

.gitignore
node_modules /
public /
	favicon.ico
	index.html
src /
	App.css
	App.js
	App.test.js
	index.css
	index.js
	logo.svg
package.json
README.md

The "root" attribute (root DOM node) within the index.html file is managed by the React DOM and is where the application will be rendered within the HTML (public/index.html). This does not have to be called "root", but we will keep it as such for now.

Once installed, the files that make up the application look like this:

				

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
    <link rel="shortcut icon" href="%PUBLIC_URL%/favicon.ico">
    <!--
      	Notice the use of %PUBLIC_URL% in the tag above.
      	It will be replaced with the URL of the `public` folder during the build.
      	Only files inside the `public` folder can be referenced from the HTML.

      	Unlike "/favicon.ico" or "favicon.ico", "%PUBLIC_URL%/favicon.ico" will
      	work correctly both with client-side routing and a non-root public URL.
      	Learn how to configure a non-root public URL by running `npm run build`.
    -->
    <title>React App</title>
</head>
<body>
    <div id="root"></div>
    <!--
      This HTML file is a template.
      If you open it directly in the browser, you will see an empty page.

      You can add webfonts, meta tags, or analytics to this file.
      The build step will place the bundled scripts into the <body> tag.

      To begin the development, run `npm start`.
      To create a production bundle, use `npm run build`.
    -->
</body>
</html>
				
			
				

body {
	margin: 0;
	padding: 0;
	font-family: sans-serif;
}
				
			
				

import React, { Component } from 'react';
import logo from './logo.svg';
import './App.css';

class App extends Component {
	render() {
    	return (
      		<div className="App">
        		<div className="App-header">
          			<img src={logo} className="App-logo" alt="logo" />
          			<h2>Welcome to React</h2>
        		</div>
        		<p className="App-intro">
          			To get started, edit <code>src/App.js</code> and save to reload.
        		</p>
      		</div>
    	);
  	}
}

export default App;
				
			
				

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';
import App from './App';

it('renders without crashing', () => {
  	const div = document.createElement('div');
  	ReactDOM.render(<App />, div);
});
				
			
				

.App {
	text-align: center;
}

.App-logo {
	animation: App-logo-spin infinite 20s linear;
	height: 80px;
}

.App-header {
	background-color: #222;
	height: 150px;
	padding: 20px;
	color: white;
}

.App-intro {
	font-size: large;
}

@keyframes App-logo-spin {
	from { transform: rotate(0deg); }
	to { transform: rotate(360deg); }
}
				
			
				

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';
import App from './App';
import './index.css';

ReactDOM.render(
  	<App />,
  	document.getElementById('root')
);

When we run the application, the browser will open and the application will be displayed.

			

$ npm start

The application running:

Hello World

To keep things very simple, we are going to remove the majority of the files that have been installed with the initial my-app application, and build an application from the ground up in React. This initial example will simply output Hello World.

Remove any unwanted files, so the my-app file structure should look like this:

			

.gitignore
node_modules /
public /
	index.html
src /
	index.js
package.json
README.md

Inside of the index.js file, remove the existing code and replace with the code example below:

				

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';

ReactDOM.render(
  <h1>Hello World</h1>,
  document.getElementById('root')
);

We also need to tidy up the index.html file where our application is to be rendered. Open the index.html file in the public directory/folder, and edit the code.

				

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="utf-8" />
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1" />
    <title>React App</title>
</head>
<body>
    
    <!-- This is where our application will render -->
    <div id="root"></div>

</body>
</html>

Notice the root attribute where our App (anything within the index.js file) will be rendered.

When we now run the application, Hello World will be displayed.

			

$ npm start

A very simple React application has been created.

If you should receive the error:

Syntax error: Adjacent JSX elements must be wrapped in an enclosing tag

You will need to wrap a <div> element around your content within your components.

Expressions

JavaScript expressions can be used inside of JSX, and just need to be wrapped inside curly brackets { ... }.

				

import React, { Component } from 'react';

class Box extends Component {
	render() {
		return (
			<div>
				// This will output 2
				<h1>{1 + 1}</h1>
			</div>
		);
	}
}

export default Box;

If / Else Statements

You cannot use If or Else statements inside JSX, but you can use conditional ternary expressions instead.

				

import React, { Component } from 'react';

class Box extends Component {
	render() {

		var x = 1;		// TRUE

		return (
			<div>
				/*
				 * If value is of x equal to 1, output TRUE
				 * Else If value of x is not equal to 1, output FALSE
				 */
				<h1>{ x === 1 ? 'True' : 'False' }</h1>
			</div>
		);

	}
}

export default Box;

Component

Components can be thought of as the widgets or modules that make up a React application. If you we're to build an application, website, page or features, it is likely that you would break it up into small components that can be used and reused. Components can be thought of like bricks of Lego.

React applications are usually constructed using components. Components are the building blocks of React. To keep things simple, a component called Box will be created within the src directory/folder of the my-app application.

Components can be combined within an application to make your application easier to maintain. This approach allows you to update and change your components without affecting the rest of the page.

The name of React components should always be uppercase. HTML tags are always lowercase.

Open the src directory/folder and create an empty file containing the following code:

				

import React, { Component } from 'react';

class Box extends Component {
	render() {
		return (
			<div class="Box">
				<p>This is the Box component</p>
			</div>
		);
	}
}

export default Box;

JavaScript didn't have classes for much of it's existance until ES6 was introduced. This allowed classes to be used as "syntactic sugar", to not create a new object-oriented inheritance model to JavaScript, but instead, provide a much simpler and clearer syntax to create objects and deal with inheritance.

Because JavaScript didn't have classes, React included it's own class system: React.createClass. This is now no-longer recommended to be used, and has been largely replaced by Components.

You can also use React.Component instead of Component if you wish to, as demonstrated below.

				

import React from 'react';

class Box extends React.Component {
	...
}

Save this file as Box.js within the src directory/folder.

The component can now be added to our application. Open the index.js file and update the code:

				

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';
import Box from './Box';

ReactDOM.render(
  <Box />,
  document.getElementById('root')
);

When the application is run, the Box component will now be displayed.

This example uses classes to create React components. This was introduced within ES6. This means we use class members to define behaviour. Because we are using Babel when using create-react-app, we can make use of ES6 syntax.

When a component has no reason to deal with states, it can be irrelevant to use a class to define a component and you can make use of functions.

				

import React from 'react';

function Box () {
	return (
		<div class="Box">
			<p>This is the Box component</p>
		</div>
	)
}

export default Box;

Adding CSS

Now that the component has been created, we are going to apply CSS to style the component for use within the application. Begin by opening an empty file within the src directory/folder, and adding the following code:

				

.Box-text {
	color: red;
}

Save the file as Box.css and we can then look to update the Box.js code to include the CSS stylesheet within our component.

				

import React, { Component } from 'react';
import './Box.css';

class Box extends Component {
	render() {
		return (
			<div class="Box">
				<p className="Box-text">This is the Box component</p>
			</div>
		);
	}
}

export default Box;

If successfully applied, the colour of the text within the Box component will now be red.

To add a class attribute to elements within a component, use the className attribute.

Adding Images to Components

As with CSS, we are now going to add an image to our Box component. Begin by adding an image file within the src directory/folder of your application.

Our example image will be called logo.svg

The image needs to then be imported into the component before being added to the component where we want it to be rendered. Open the Box.js component file and update the code:

				

import React, { Component } from 'react';
import logo from './logo.svg';
import './Box.css';

class Box extends Component {
	render() {
		return (
			<div class="Box">
				<p className="Box-text">This is the Box component</p>
				<img src={logo} alt="logo" />
			</div>
		);
	}
}

export default Box;

The logo will be rendered beneath the text within the component. We can update the CSS to style the logo using the className attribute.

}

The CSS code:

	color: red;
}

.Box-logo {
	height: 80px;
}

Props

There are two types of "model" data in React: props and state.

Props is short for properties. They are passed into the component. The JSX attributes being set on elements within a component, like className, are props. When a component is rendered, it can access it's props using this.props.

Any UI library will always provide a way to pass data around the system. React uses the props object to do this. Dynamic apps must have a way to pass data around it's system. In React, this mostly happens among components and external services that provide the original data, such as: HTTP and LocalStorage.

Here is example code:

				

import React, { Component } from 'react';
import logo from './logo.svg';
import './Box.css';

class Box extends Component {
	render() {
		return (
			<h1>Hello {this.props.name}</h1>
		);
	}
}

export default Box;

Then, within the index.js file, we can pass a value of Dan.

				

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';
import Box from './Box';

ReactDOM.render(
  <Box name="Dan" />,
  document.getElementById('root')
);

The application will output Hello Dan inside the browser. The line of code, below, creates a property of name with the value Dan. This property is passed into the component, similar to how an argument is passed into a function. In this example, the props is coming from the parent.

				

<Box name="Dan" />,

During a component's lifecycle, props should not change and should be considered immutable.

setProps and replaceProps are both deprecated and should not be used.

State

At the heart of every React component is it's state, an object that determines how the component renders and behaves. This is what allows you to create components that are dynamic and interactive.

Like props, state holds information about the component. By default, a component has no state - it is said to be stateless.

If you are using ES6, you should initialize state within the constructor, else, use the getInitialState() method.

When a component needs to keep track of information between renderings, the component itself can create, update and use the state.

As a simple example, we will create a button that keeps track of how many times you've clicked it. Lets begin by creating a new component called Button in a file named Button.js.

				

import React, { Component } from 'react';

class Button extends Component {

	constructor() {
		super();
		// 1. The component is initialised and state.count is set to 0
		this.state = {
			count: 0
		};
	}

	updateCount() {
		/*
		 * 4. Call setState() if the updateCount() method is called, 
		 * with a call back to increase the counter from the previous state
		 */
		this.setState((prevState, props) => {
			/* 5. Trigger a call to render
			return { count: prevState.count + 1 }
		});
	}

	render() {
		return (

			// 3. If the button is clicked, call the updateCount() method
			<button onClick={() => this.updateCount()}>
				// 2. The component renders with 'Clicked 0 times' as the button text
				Clicked {this.state.count} times
			</button>

		);
	}
}

export default Button;

Now that a new component has been created, it will need to be added to the index.js file so it can be included within our application.

				

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';
import Box from './Box';
import Button from './Button';

ReactDOM.render(
  <Box name="Dan" />,
  <Button />,
  document.getElementById('root')
);

Now, when the application is run, a button will be present. Each time the button is clicked, the count will increment by 1.

The main difference between state and props, is that state is created in the component and gets it's initial data - hardcoded - from within the constructor. However, data can also come from props.

The other main difference is that: state is changeable. In the example above, we are using state to keep a track of the total number of clicks.

setState updates the object/state of the component and re-renders the component automatically. prevState is placed within the callback to contain the previous state, so even if the state has been updated elsewhere.

It is always recommended to use setState and not write something like:

				

// Bad example - avoid when using React
this.state.count = this.state.count + 1

React will be unable to listen to the state getting updated in this way and the component will not re-render.

setState is asynchronous, so another example to avoid using can be found below, as it may cause errors with out-of-sync state data:

				

// Bad example - avoid when using React
this.setState({
	count: this.state.count + 1
});

The example above uses the ES6 Arrow function. When the button is clicked, the updateCount() method will be called. We use the ES6 Arrow function so that updateCount() will have access to the instance's state.

				

onClick={() => this.updateCount()}
